stages.heading: Life Processes
stages.content: All living beings need food for energy to perform basic activities. We also need energy for playing, singing, reading, etc.

stages.heading: Machines
stages.content: Machines also need energy for their working. Some engines require fuel like petrol and diesel.

stages.heading: Connection
stages.content: Work, energy, and power are closely related concepts that help us understand natural phenomena.

stages.heading: Difference in Meaning
stages.content: There is a difference between 'work' in day-to-day life and 'work' in science. Mental labour like studying is not considered work in science.

stages.heading: No Displacement, No Work
stages.content: Pushing a huge rock that doesn't move involves a lot of effort but no work is done on the rock because there is no displacement.

stages.heading: The Conditions
stages.content: For work to be done in science, two conditions must be satisfied: (i) a force should act on an object, and (ii) the object must be displaced.

stages.heading: Examples
stages.content: A girl pulling a trolley is doing work because force is applied and displacement occurs. A book lifted up involves work.

topics.title: Work Done by a Constant Force

stages.heading: Definition
stages.content: Work done by a force acting on an object is equal to the magnitude of the force multiplied by the distance moved in the direction of the force.

stages.heading: Formula
stages.content: Work (W) = Force (F) × Displacement (s). Work has only magnitude and no direction.

stages.heading: Unit
stages.content: The unit of work is newton metre (N m) or joule (J). 1 J is the work done when a force of 1 N displaces an object by 1 m.

stages.heading: Positive Work
stages.content: Work done is positive when the force is in the direction of displacement. Example: A baby pulling a toy car parallel to the ground.

stages.heading: Negative Work
stages.content: Work done is negative when the force acts opposite to the direction of displacement. Example: Retarding force applied to a moving object.

stages.heading: Capacity to Do Work
stages.content: An object having a capability to do work is said to possess energy. The object doing work loses energy, and the object on which work is done gains energy.

stages.heading: Measurement
stages.content: Energy possessed by an object is measured in terms of its capacity of doing work. The unit of energy is the same as work: joule (J).

stages.heading: Sources
stages.content: The Sun is the biggest natural source of energy. Other sources include nuclei of atoms, interior of earth, and tides.

stages.heading: Variety
stages.content: Energy exists in many forms: mechanical energy (potential + kinetic), heat energy, chemical energy, electrical energy, and light energy.

stages.heading: Energy of Motion
stages.content: Kinetic energy is the energy possessed by an object due to its motion. A moving bullet, blowing wind, and a running athlete possess kinetic energy.

stages.heading: Speed Factor
stages.content: The kinetic energy of an object increases with its speed. An object moving faster can do more work than an identical object moving relatively slow.

stages.heading: Derivation
stages.content: Work done to accelerate an object from velocity u to v is the change in kinetic energy. If starting from rest (u=0), Work = ½mv².

stages.heading: Formula
stages.content: Kinetic Energy (Ek) = ½mv², where m is the mass and v is the velocity.

stages.heading: Stored Energy
stages.content: The energy transferred to an object is stored as potential energy if it is not used to cause a change in velocity. It is the energy present by virtue of position or configuration.

stages.heading: Examples
stages.content: Stretching a rubber band or winding a toy car stores potential energy.

topics.title: Potential Energy of an Object at a Height

stages.heading: Gravitational Potential Energy
stages.content: When an object is raised through a height, work is done against gravity. The energy gained is gravitational potential energy.

stages.heading: Formula
stages.content: Ep = mgh, where m is mass, g is acceleration due to gravity, and h is the height.

stages.heading: Path Independence
stages.content: The work done by gravity depends on the difference in vertical heights, not on the path taken.

stages.heading: Transformation
stages.content: Energy can be converted from one form to another. In nature, green plants convert solar energy to chemical energy (food).

stages.heading: Gadgets
stages.content: Many human activities and gadgets involve energy conversion, like an electric bulb converting electrical energy to light and heat.

stages.heading: Statement
stages.content: Energy can only be converted from one form to another; it can neither be created nor destroyed. The total energy before and after the transformation remains the same.

stages.heading: Free Fall Example
stages.content: During free fall, potential energy decreases while kinetic energy increases. The sum (mechanical energy) remains constant at all points: mgh + ½mv² = constant.

stages.heading: Definition
stages.content: Power is defined as the rate of doing work or the rate of transfer of energy. Power = Work / Time.

stages.heading: Unit
stages.content: The unit of power is watt (W). 1 W = 1 Joule/second. Larger unit is kilowatt (kW).

stages.heading: Average Power
stages.content: Since power may vary with time, we use average power = Total energy consumed / Total time taken.

stages.heading: Kilowatt-hour
stages.content: The joule is too small for large energy quantities. We use kilowatt-hour (kWh). 1 kWh is the energy used in one hour at the rate of 1000 J/s.

stages.heading: Conversion
stages.content: 1 kWh = 3.6 x 10^6 J. This is commonly known as one 'unit' of electricity.
